p: Previously, bacterial identification based on host protein signatures was challenging for ancient specimens. For example , the presence of the agent of tuberculosis, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, in archaeological human remains was suggested by osteological examination and easily confirmed by biomolecular techniques. MALDI‐TOF MS, a new approach by proteomics, identified M. tuberculosis from human ancient bone samples through spectra of proteins (Boros‐Major et al., 2011; Hajdu et al., 2012) and mycolic acids (Mark, Patonai, Vaczy, Lorand, & Marcsik, 2010). Then, an article revealed that the presence of mycolic acids of M. tuberculosis in the previous research was not enough evidence to have confirmation (Minnikin, Lee, Pitts, Baird, & Besra, 2010). Furthermore, a study in 2016 showed the difficulties of protein identification from M. tuberculosis because of the lack of specific proteins, the peptide mass fingerprint used in these researches was not so different from human collagen (Hendy et al., 2016).
